conclusion: To determine the power of the external force doing work, we need to follow these steps:
The conductor rod OC is rotating in a uniform magnetic field B. The length of the conductor rod OC is r.

premise: The conductor rod OC is rotating in a uniform magnetic field B. The length of the conductor rod OC is r.
conclusion: The induced emf (𝓔) in a conductor rotating in a magnetic field is given by: 𝓔 = B ⋅ v ⋅ r where v is the tangential velocity of the point C relative to the center O.
Since OC rotates uniformly with an angular velocity ω, the tangential velocity v at point C is: v = ω ⋅ r
Substituting v = ω ⋅ r into the emf formula: 𝓔 = B ⋅ (ω ⋅ r) ⋅ r = B ⋅ ω ⋅ r²
The current I through the resistor R is given by Ohm's law: I = 𝓔/R. Substituting the value of 𝓔: I = (B ⋅ ω ⋅ r²)/R
The power P dissipated in the resistor R is given by: P = I² ⋅ R. Substituting the value of I: P = ((B ⋅ ω ⋅ r²)/R)² ⋅ R
Simplifying the expression: P = (B² ⋅ ω² ⋅ r⁴)/R
The power of the external force doing work is: (B² ⋅ ω² ⋅ r⁴)/R
